outputs.description: By the end of 2016, the child protection system applies a case management approach to its child clients and ensures theavailability and functioning of specialized services in accordance with international standards and best interests of children
Actions related to setting the direction and governance of country programme operations and office structures, including businesscontinuity and risk management.
Human resources have the capacities, skills, morale and motivation to support country operations
National capacities are strengthened for developing evidence-based policies and for effectively monitoring their implementation.
Public and private (corporate and individual) sectors are supported to increase their engagement and investment in the protectionand realization of child rights in Croatia and abroad.
Sustainable platforms for the exchange of knowledge and best practices between Croatia and other countries are established.
Children, especially those from vulnerable groups, are supported to access child rights institutions.
Guidance, tools and resources for effective communication, advocacy and partnerships on child rights issues with stakeholders areavailable to UNICEF and its partners.
Strategies to address cross-cutting issues related to child rights are developed and applied throughout the programme ofcooperation
Guidance, tools and resources to effectively generate, analyse, and utilize statistical and qualitative information for ChildRights Monitoring system are available in the country.
Non staff costs
CROATIA 2007 - 2011

Models of inclusive ECE services (equal accessibility and quality education) as well as integrated ECI policies (timelymultidisciplinary and multisector intervention) are identified established, tested, documented and validated.
By the end of 2016, national and local authorities provide quality, inclusive community-based parenting and ECD support services tothe most disadvantaged boys and girls and their families.
National capacities are strengthened to promote and support inclusive ECE and integrated ECI policies for the most vulnerablechildren.

National and local authorities have evidence, best practices and technical advice on driving legislation, improving financialresourcing and implementing the inclusive ECE and integrated ECI policies for the most vulnerable children.
Effective & efficient Sales

By the end of 2016, the social welfare and health system, in cooperation with local authorities, provides comprehensive, quality,accessible and responsive home-based early childhood intervention services to most vulnerable families and children
Human resources have the capacities, skills, morale and motivation to support country operations
Private Sector Fundraising
Professionals involved in child protection and justice have strengthened capacities for effective implementation and monitoring ofchild-friendly and gender-sensitive justice.

Social welfare, education and health professionals have enhanced capacities for provision of inclusive family and community-basedservices for the most vulnerable children, including children affected by emergency situations.
All relevant stakeholders have evidence and technical advice on driving legislation and budgeting for child protection.
Parent-support programmes reach particularly vulnerable families.
UNICEF staff and partners are provided tools, guidance and resources for effective advocacy and partnerships on child rights issueswith stakeholders.
PRIOR-YEAR COMMITMENTS
Strategies to address cross-cutting issues related to child rights are developed and applied
